item.title: About
item.description: I am a protein biochemist by training, but a biologist with broad interests that range from the atomic to organismal scale in principle. I have a B.S. in Bioengineering from Binghamton University and a Ph.D. in Genetics from the University of Chicago. As a computational biologist in the lab of Manuel Llinás, I contributed to studies of transcriptional regulation in Plasmodium falciparum, which inspired me pursue a Ph.D. in order to learn more about life at the molecular scale.

item.title: Research
item.description: Cytokine engineering in the Mendoza Lab Coming soon! Molecular immunology in the Adams Lab Coming sooner! Plasmodium computational genomics in the Llinás Lab As a member of the Llinás Lab I contributed to work in understanding transcriptional regulation in the deadliest human infecting parasite that causes malaria, Plasmodium falciparum. Primary contributions resulted in the following publications: Red Blood Cell Invasion by the Malaria Parasite Is Coordinated by the PfAP2-I Transcription Factor Refining the transcriptome of the human malaria parasite Plasmodium falciparum using amplification-free RNA-seq Want to invstigate our data yourself?
